author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Go Up in Smoke
description: Grant Thackray alights with an incendiary Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Well, everybody, back to school! This is a pretty tough grid, with an added factor that we see occasionally: It looks a little ugly when it’s finished, because the theme includes some entries that “go the wrong way.” I don’t think that’s a spoiler, but it is something you can show the person looking over your shoulder and pointing out all your mistakes — always so helpful when you’re hard at work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: Threats and Fear Cause Afghan Women’s Protections to Vanish Overnight
description: As the Taliban advanced, safe houses for women closed, and the staff sheltered girls at home as relatives released from prison threatened to kill them.
content: It took years for Women for Afghan Women to build up Afghanistan’s largest network of women’s protection services — 32 safe houses, family guidance centers and children’s homes in 14 provinces, growing by word of mouth and driven by the intense need for their services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Michaux
title: At the Tour Championship, Patrick Reed is All About the Ryder Cup
description: A few weeks ago the golfer was in the I.C.U. “battling” for his life. Now it is his last chance to show he’s ready to join the American side for the Ryder Cup.
content: ATLANTA — Ostensibly, Patrick Reed drove 15 hours from Texas to Georgia on Tuesday in the back of a van to chase the FedEx Cup title and the largest possible share of the $46 million on offer at the season-ending Tour Championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Keith McCants, Football Star Laid Low by Drugs, Dies at 53
description: At one time the N.F.L.’s highest-paid defensive player, he left the league after six seasons and fell into a spiral of addiction, homelessness and desolation.
content: In N.F.L. parlance, Keith McCants was a “can’t miss.” A relentless and powerful athlete, he was a first-team all-American linebacker at Alabama and was drafted fourth overall in 1990 by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. His success seemingly guaranteed, the team made him the highest-paid defensive player in the league.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Someone Who Has It All
description: Byron Walden has it in for us, it seems.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is the second time in two weeks that I found myself a bit buffeted by a difficult Saturday grid. Some of us probably saw its byline and predicted a difficult road ahead; this is Byron Walden’s 65th Saturday puzzle for The Times (and his 102nd overall).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Lara Jakes, Michael D. Shear and Michael Crowley
title: In Afghan Withdrawal, a Biden Doctrine Surfaces
description: The messy ending to the war has underscored President Biden’s discomfort with prolonged military engagements, even as the United States faces complex new threats.
content: WASHINGTON — In the chaotic finale of America’s 20-year war in Afghanistan, a Biden Doctrine is emerging: a foreign policy that avoids the aggressive tactics of forever wars and nation building, while uniting allies against the authoritarianism of rising powers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Patricia Maginnis, Pioneering Abortion-Rights Activist, Dies at 93
description: In the years before Roe v. Wade, she helped shift the debate away from the rules governing abortion providers to women’s right to control their bodies.
content: Patricia Maginnis, one of the nation’s earliest and fiercest proponents of a woman’s right to safe, legal abortions, who crusaded for that right on her own before the formation of an organized reproductive-rights movement, died on Aug. 30 in Oakland, Calif. She was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Canadian health officials warn of an ‘urgent need’ to vaccinate young adults.
description: The call from Public Health Agency of Canada came as the highly contagious Delta variant has driven up cases and hospitalizations in recent weeks.
content: As another wave of coronavirus cases and hospitalizations rises in parts of Canada, its public health agency is urging young people, a lagging demographic in the country’s vaccination campaign, to roll up their sleeves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag, Patrick McGeehan and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: Lower Manhattan Rebounded After 9/11, but the Pandemic Erased the Gains
description: The triumphant comeback of Lower Manhattan after 2001 became a rallying cry for New York City. But its offices have emptied out, tourists are gone, and hundreds of retailers have shut down.
content: The Amish Market opened in 1999 in the shadow of the World Trade Center, one of the few grocery stores and delis for residents and workers in the southernmost tip of Manhattan. Two years later, the 110-story twin towers at the complex collapsed in the Sept. 11 attacks, showering the store in fiery debris and ash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2021 U.S. Open: What to Watch on Saturday
description: Novak Djokovic and Ashleigh Barty feature at Arthur Ashe Stadium as the third round of singles play concludes.
content: How to watch: From 11 a.m. to 11 p.m. Eastern time on ESPN2; and streaming on the ESPN app. In Canada on TSN from 11 a.m. to 11 p.m.; and streaming on TSN.ca and the TSN app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Lane Kiffin, football coach at Ole Miss, will miss Monday’s game after a positive test.
description: The coach and his staff and players have all been vaccinated. He said he has had only mild symptoms.
content: Lane Kiffin, the head football coach at the University of Mississippi, said Saturday that he had tested positive for the coronavirus and would miss Monday night’s game against the University of Louisville, the season opener for both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Zanele Mji
title: Indian vs. Black: Vigilante Killings Upend a South African Town
description: As rioting and looting swept the country this summer, Indians in the suburb of Phoenix set up roadblocks to police their streets. Dozens of Black people passing through wound up dead.
content: PHOENIX, South Africa — The blows thundered down — bats, a hammer, a field hockey stick — as Njabulo Dlamini lay curled on the pavement, trying to summon the strength to move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Delores Custer, 79, Dies; Gave Star Turns to Cornflakes and Noodles
description: A longtime food stylist for big-name companies, she was a master of the craft and taught students all over the world how to sweat a glass or perfect the pizza cheese pull.
content: Delores Custer, a food stylist who made stars out of hamburgers and cocktails, cereals and crackers that twinkled from magazine pages and television screens, died on Aug. 18 at her home in Portland, Ore. She was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully, Kevin Armstrong and Sean Piccoli
title: New Jersey’s Stunning Storm Toll Includes Many Who Drowned in Cars
description: Hurricane Ida killed at least 25 people in New Jersey — more fatalities than in any other state — as the monster storm whipped its way onto the Gulf Coast and tore north to New England.
content: Malathi Kanche was heading home after dropping her son off at college Wednesday evening when the small S.U.V. she was driving was overwhelmed by floodwaters set off by the remnants of Hurricane Ida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: Welcome to our latest PandA specialist, Michael Lieberman.
content: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — So, did anyone think of this old ad campaign when they solved the pun-filled acrostic last weekend?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Greenhouse
title: How Biden Can Help Democrats Become the Party of the Working Class Again
description: Posing at coal mines and factories, they may tell voters otherwise. But the policy tells a different story.
content: This past spring, Representative Jim Banks of Indiana, chairman of the House Republican Study Committee, wrote a curious policy memo, with the subject line “URGENT: Cementing GOP as the Working-Class Party.” He argued that Republicans should look to nail down working-class support through tough immigration policies, a crusade against “Wokeness,” and attacks against tech companies that “censor” Donald Trump and other conservatives, among other policies. The memo honored a time-tested Republican tradition: Wooing working-class voters by focusing not on economic issues like higher pay and runaway health care costs, but on polarizing social issues, like abortion and same-sex marriage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Kentucky’s schools struggle as coronavirus outbreaks close entire districts.
description: The state has reached its highest levels of cases and hospitalizations since the start of the pandemic.
content: About a fifth of Kentucky’s school districts have had to temporarily close since classes began last month because of coronavirus infections, an indication of the dire impact the most recent wave of the virus has had on the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordan Gale and Sergio Olmos
title: When Hard Jobs Turn Hazardous
description: As drought, record heat and wildfire smoke seize the Pacific Northwest, farm owners and fieldworkers struggle to adapt. Sometimes the response feels improvised or inadequate.
content: In early summer, a day laborer laying irrigation lines at a plant nursery just south of Portland, Ore., collapsed to the ground and died. His official cause of death was declared “heat related.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Emma Goldberg
title: Health experts keep warning against using ivermectin as a Covid treatment. Some Americans refuse to listen.
description: The drug has spared hundreds of millions of Africans from serious parasites, but clinical trials have repeatedly failed to show that it is effective against Covid. Still, U.S. demand is high.
content: A doctor in rural Oklahoma says hospitals are backed up with patients who have overdosed on veterinary ivermectin, an anti-parasite medication. Mississippi’s health department said that 70 percent of recent calls to the state poison control center in August came from people who ingested ivermectin from livestock supply stores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Pete and Chasten Buttigieg Welcome 2 Children to Their Family
description: In posts on Twitter and Instagram, the couple shared the first photograph of their newborn son and daughter.
content: Pete Buttigieg, the transportation secretary, said on Saturday that he and his husband, Chasten, were now the parents of two children, making him the first openly gay cabinet secretary to become a parent while in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan A. Knee
title: Network Effects Are Overrated
description: Netflix provides a stark example of the tendency to exaggerate the role of network effects and AI.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offer a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Nearly a Week Without Power, New Orleans Is Facing a ‘Race With the Clock’
description: Forecasters are warning of dangerously high temperatures this weekend as 70 percent of the city remains without power after Hurricane Ida.
content: NEW ORLEANS — When Stephanie Crier emerged from her New Orleans apartment last week after hunkering down for Hurricane Ida, she was relieved to find that the storm had not flooded the city or left catastrophic destruction on par with Hurricane Katrina. But since then, things have only gotten worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis
title: Signature Moves With Sean Bankhead
description: The choreographer behind many of the biggest music videos of the year is a pop star’s secret weapon.
content: Last year, when Cardi B’s team reached out to the choreographer Sean Bankhead to help create dances for the “Up” music video, he asked if she had two months to dedicate to learning them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Liz Lange Lets the Sun Into Grey Gardens
description: The designer who made her name in maternity wear is telling-all in a new podcast about the infamous Steinberg family.
content: When Liz Lange walks you through Grey Gardens — the East Hampton home made famous by the 1975 documentary that showcased its eccentric inhabitants living in transcendent squalor — you will notice that very little is gray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sona Patel
title: How Your Comments Make Our Journalism Better
description: Reader responses add an extra dimension to Times articles, and a lot more.
content: In a recent interview with the late-night TV host James Corden, the singer-songwriter Lorde described how a self-imposed break from social media prompted her to find company in a popular comments section of The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Naomi Osaka Is Out at U.S. Open and May Take a Break From Tennis
description: In tears after the third-round loss to Leylah Fernandez, the defending champion said she did not know when she would play her next tennis match.
content: This was never the way it was supposed to go for Naomi Osaka, the biggest new star in tennis, whose fame, reach and success appeared to have no limits at the start of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi and Sebastián López Brach
title: An Economic Lifeline in South America, the Paraná River, Is Shriveling
description: The continent’s second-largest river is drying up amid the biggest drought in 70 years, upending ecosystems, trade and livelihoods.
content: ROSARIO, Argentina — The fisherman woke up early on a recent morning, banged on the fuel containers on his small boat to make sure he had enough for the day, and set out on the Paraná River, fishing net in hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: How We Built a 3-D Model of the Collapsed Surfside Condo Tower
description: A team of journalists examined building plans and interviewed a dozen experts to understand how the building could have failed.
content: More than two months after the collapse of the Champlain Towers South building in Surfside, Fla., on June 24, a central question remains: How did this happen? An official investigation continues, but so far there are only theories and no official consensus on the cause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: For Tribal Members in Oklahoma, Medicaid Expansion Improves Access to Specialty Care
description: Medicaid expansion is expected to improve not just access to care for low-income Native Americans who had previously been shut out of health insurance, but the finances of the Indian Health Service.
content: TAHLEQUAH, Okla. — There’s a saying in Indian Country: “Don’t get sick after June.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis
title: How a Surprise Discovery of Photographs From the 1960s Meets the Moment
description: A trove of images were found in a photographer’s family home. Now they are part of an exhibition opening next week in Harlem that captures pivotal years in the Black Panther Party.
content: Not long after his mother passed away in 2018, a massive relic from Jeffrey Henson Scales’ childhood was unexpectedly found in his family’s home. His stepfather and older brother were preparing the house for an eventual sale when they came across a trove of 40 rolls of film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: The Return of the Dream Honeymoon
description: Mini-moons and short road trips to explore local destinations may still be trending, but couples are also back to booking proper romantic getaways in faraway places.
content: When Kalyn and Collin Pounders finally went on their honeymoon to Greece in July after delaying it for more than a year because of the pandemic, they were ready to splurge. The couple, who live in Atlanta and married in June 2020, extended their trip so that they were able to visit Mykonos and Santorini islands, got a nicer room at the hotel they had booked and even went on a private cruise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The American Empire in Retreat
description: There are very few paths back to just being an ordinary nation that don’t involve a truly wrenching fall.
content: In one of the more arresting videos that circulated after the fall of Kabul, a journalist follows a collection of Taliban fighters into a hangar containing abandoned, disabled U.S. helicopters. Except that the fighters don’t look like our idea of the Taliban: In their gear and guns and helmets (presumably pilfered), they look exactly like the American soldiers their long insurgency defeated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Beavers Re-emerge in Scotland, Drawing Ire of Farmers
description: Building dams that flood land, the beavers have infuriated farmers. Some have obtained permits to kill the animals — setting off outrage among conservationists.
content: EDINBURGH — Wrapped inside a brown hessian sack, the baby beaver wriggled as it was carried to an examination table, but gave up the fight as a veterinarian deftly punched a microchip into its thick pelt and removed clumps of brown fur for samples.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Taliban Fighters Crush a Women’s Protest Amid Flickers of Resistance
description: The women were assaulted with rifle butts, tear gas and metal clubs, while anti-Taliban rebels in the north vowed to repel an assault by the Islamist group.
content: Taliban fighters violently suppressed a women’s protest Saturday in Kabul, while 70 miles to the north ex-Afghan army and militia members battled the Islamist group in Panjshir Province, as pockets of anti-Taliban resistance continued to flare up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Sophie Kasakove and Christopher Flavelle
title: Ida Reveals Two Louisianas: One With Storm Walls, Another Without
description: A massive flood protection system built around New Orleans helped save it from flooding during Hurricane Ida. Surrounding communities, which weren’t so lucky, want their own system.
content: LAROSE, La. — After Hurricane Katrina, an ambitious and expensive system of levees, walls, storm gates and pumps was installed around New Orleans to protect against the kind of flooding and horror that so deeply scarred the city, and the nation, in 2005. And when Hurricane Ida hit last week, exactly 16 years later, those hopes were largely fulfilled. The flooding was minimal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giri Nathan
title: There’s a GameStop Book, Already
description: With “The Antisocial Network,” Ben Mezrich does for January’s infamous short squeeze what he did for Facebook with “The Accidental Billionaires.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: 5 Missing Sailors Declared Dead After Helicopter Crash
description: The sailors had been missing since Tuesday after the helicopter, an MH-60S, crashed into the sea near San Diego, the Navy said.
content: Five sailors were declared dead on Saturday after a U.S. Navy helicopter crashed off the coast near San Diego on Tuesday, military officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Questions Swirl After Yet Another Emmett Till Sign Comes Down
description: A historical marker that stood outside the Mississippi shop where 14-year-old Emmett Till encountered the woman who accused him of whistling at her, may have been toppled by a truck. But a historical center is reluctant to call it an accident.
content: When it was notified this week that another sign commemorating Emmett Till had disappeared, the Emmett Till Interpretive Center had every reason to be worried.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Autor
title: Good News: There’s a Labor Shortage.
description: Workers have decided they're not content to settle for demeaning, low-paid work. Can employers take the hint?
content: Many employers are alarmed about the current labor shortage — the phenomenon of a labor market with more job openings than unemployed workers. There are two supposed problems, they allege. First, that the labor shortage is caused by government benefits that discourage work. And second, that the shortage will harm the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Michaels and David Noll
title: We Are Becoming a Nation of Vigilantes
description: The Texas abortion law is just an opening salvo in a broader push by conservatives to restrict the rights of their neighbors, classmates and colleagues.
content: In the seemingly endless battle to deny disfavored groups equal citizenship, Republican lawmakers around the country have repurposed an old tool to new and cruel effect. They’ve inverted private enforcement laws — marshaled over the years to discipline fraudulent government contractors, racist or sexist bosses and toxic polluters — to enable individuals to suppress the rights of their neighbors, classmates and colleagues. Most prominent among these new laws is SB 8, Texas’s heartbeat bill. The law bans abortions six weeks after conception, lets anyone bring a lawsuit against medical practitioners who violate the ban and provides cash bounties of at least $10,000 (plus legal fees and costs) to encourage such litigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: In Invoking Beau, Biden Broaches a Loss That’s Guided His Presidency
description: Referring to Beau Biden with families of U.S. Marines killed in the Kabul airport bombing drew criticism, but the president remains haunted by memories of a son he described as “me, but without all the downsides.”
content: WASHINGTON — In the hours before Lance Cpl. Jared Schmitz, 20, was killed by a terrorist’s bomb in Afghanistan, he posed for a photograph taken by a bunkmate. In the image, the Marine’s brow was furrowed. He flashed a peace sign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: ‘Sexist,’ ‘Racist,’ ‘Classist’: Georgia 8th Grader Challenges School Dress Code
description: After being cited for a rip in her jeans on the first day of school, Sophia Trevino has led a protest seeking changes to the district’s dress code, which she says unfairly targets girls.
content: Sophia Trevino carefully picked her outfit the night before her first day of eighth grade last month. Two hours before bedtime, and with her mother’s help, she went through her closet and selected a white Los Angeles T-shirt, a new pair of black distressed jeans and Air Force 1 sneakers. Sophia, 13, of course checked with her friends that the outfit was cute; they said it was. Her parents didn’t think twice about the clothes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: New York Planned for Fierce Storms. But It Wasn’t Ready for This.
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 4, 2021.
content: “The subway system is not a submarine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margalit Fox
title: Willard Scott, TV’s Clown Prince of Sun and Showers, Is Dead at 87
description: Mr. Scott, who played both Bozo the Clown and the original Ronald McDonald on television, was a longtime weather forecaster on the “Today” show who emphasized showmanship over science.
content: Willard Scott, the antic longtime weather forecaster on the “Today” show, whose work, by his own cheerful acknowledgment, made it clear that you don’t need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows, died on Saturday at his farm in Delaplane, Va. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: How Has Joe Biden Become So Unpopular?
description: Putting presidential approval in context.
content: President Biden’s job approval rating is on the downslope. As of Friday morning he was at 45.8 percent approval and 48.5 percent disapproval — from a high of 54 percent approval, 41 percent disapproval at the end of his first 100 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Ruth Graham
title: Texas Judge Grants Restraining Order Against Anti-Abortion Group
description: The order’s effect is narrow, as it will prevent Texas Right to Life and its associates from suing Planned Parenthood only until Sept. 17.
content: A Texas judge granted a temporary restraining order against the state’s largest anti-abortion group on Friday, blocking it from suing Planned Parenthood under the terms of the restrictive abortion law that went into effect this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How Do I Hold a Co-op Board Accountable for Discrimination?
description: A co-op board can reject an applicant for almost any reason, but it cannot discriminate. But how can discrimination be proved?
content: Q: My partner and I submitted an application to buy a co-op in Dumbo, but the board rejected us despite our solid financials and a sterling board package. Our broker told us it was because of our dogs, even though the co-op is pet friendly and we submitted numerous character references for the dogs. I suspect a different reason: The day before the rejection, we were asked to submit a family photo. I think they rejected us because I am a person of color and covered in tattoos. What recourse do we have?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Why Does Playing Tennis Make So Many Pros Miserable?
description: Naomi Osaka is taking an indefinite break from tennis as she struggles to find meaning and joy from playing. It’s a sadly familiar script for the sport.
content: The moment resonated with nearly every player who has ever picked up a racket, and especially those who have reached the pinnacle of tennis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Drowning Our Future in the Past
description: Republicans keep dragging us backward.
content: WASHINGTON — It isn’t a pretty picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Leylah Fernandez, Who Beat Osaka, Leads a Canadian Charge
description: Canada’s high-performance tennis program is achieving its goal of producing elite players, several of whom have advanced at the U.S. Open.
content: The Canadian flag is everywhere at the U.S. Open, where Canadian players are winning on courts across the grounds and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Blacki Migliozzi
title: Satellite Images Find ‘Substantial’ Oil Spill in Gulf After Ida
description: Satellite and aerial survey images show oil spreading off the coast of an oil and gas hub in Louisiana.
content: Cleanup crews are working to contain what experts called a substantial oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, according to an examination of satellite and aerial survey images, ship tracking data and interviews with local officials and others involved in the spill response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: As Kashmir Crackdown Endures, Poets Stifle Their Verses
description: Harsh measures against dissent have trickled down to practitioners of the region’s poetic traditions, with many saying they have been told to stop.
content: BALHAMA, Kashmir — As the sun slipped behind the Himalayas, the poet picked his way down to the rocky riverbed. He looked left and right to make sure nobody was watching. Then, to the burbling water, he began to read:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Your Finances Took a Hit From the Pandemic. Here’s What You Do Now.
description: Find someone wiser than you, check your credit report and taxes, and stop catastrophizing. This is how you can do it.
content: Maybe you lost your job. Maybe your hours were cut. Or maybe you had to take over caregiving responsibilities. If your income fell precipitously in the last 18 months — even if things have gotten better — it’s an uncertain time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Frankel
title: The Forgotten Jews of the Forest
description: More than 70 years after World War II, we're still learning about new facets of the Holocaust.
content: On an unseasonably cold night in August 1942, Miriam Rabinowitz pushed her way past a wooden fence topped with barbed wire and broke out of the ghetto in Zdzięciol, Poland. She wasn’t alone. The 34-year-old woman led her two young daughters, her sister, a cousin, and a handful of others away from the underground bunker where they had hidden for three days while SS squads rounded up some 2,500 other Jewish men, women and children, marched them to the edge of town, forced them to strip naked and shot them into waiting pits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Missouri Relocates Gay History Exhibit From State Capitol
description: The exhibit, which examined Kansas City’s contributions to the gay rights movement, was supposed to be in the Capitol building until the end of the year.
content: On Monday, a traveling exhibit about gay history began a planned four-month display in the Missouri Capitol. By Wednesday night, it was gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Curtis Flowers Sues Prosecutor Who Tried Him Six Times
description: Charges were dropped in 2019 against Mr. Flowers, who spent 23 years in prison after he was accused of killing four people at a Mississippi furniture store.
content: Curtis Flowers was arrested in 1997 after being accused of killing four people at a furniture store in Mississippi. He spent 23 years in prison until he was released in 2019, and charges against him were dropped the following year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Democrats Hit the Road to Sell Big Spending Bills as Republicans Attack
description: Lawmakers seek to win the backing of voters by emphasizing the tangible benefits of sweeping legislation that Congress will consider in the coming weeks.
content: LAWSON, Colo. — Standing alongside Clear Creek, a popular white-water rafting destination in this gateway to the Rocky Mountains west of Denver, Senator Michael Bennet delivered his pitch for $60 billion in new spending to protect the state’s forests and watersheds against recurring fires and their widespread impact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: After Stabbing Attack, New Zealand Examines Its Antiterrorism Efforts
description: A man who wounded seven people in a supermarket had been under surveillance for months. Officials say a loophole in the country’s laws needs to be closed.
content: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — When Ahamed Aathill Mohamed Samsudeen grabbed a knife at a Countdown supermarket on Friday in West Auckland and began stabbing shoppers, the police were just outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: New York’s Mayor Outlines Rain-Preparedness Plan
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York announced new measures for rain emergencies, driven by climate change, including issuing weather-related travel bans and quickly evacuating people in basement apartments and other areas at high risk for flooding.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York announced new measures for rain emergencies, driven by climate change, including issuing weather-related travel bans and quickly evacuating people in basement apartments and other areas at high risk for flooding.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coach Coughlin and the Caregiver’s Love and Heartbreak
description: Readers are moved by the football coach’s account of caring for his seriously ill wife and offer personal stories and advice.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 4, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 4, 2021.
content: An article on Friday about the deaths of four Louisiana nursing home residents misspelled the  parish that was home to a 77-year-old man who died. He was from Terrebonne Parish, not Terrebone.
source.name: The New York Times
